Award.AwardTitle: IOS: Specification, Patterning and Evolution of the Animal-Vegetal Axis
Award.AbstractNarration: An early critical step during animal development is the separation of ectoderm, cells that produce the epidermis (skin) and central nervous system (brain/spinal cord), from endomesoderm, the cells that produce the intestine and internal organs. In most animals this process is strongly influenced by a molecular polarity present in the unfertilized egg termed the Animal-Vegetal (AV) axis. In general, cells derived from the egg's animal pole produce ectoderm, while vegetal pole-derived cells produce endomesoderm. This separation of developmental potential is frequently mediated by localized activation of a highly conserved signaling cascade called the canonical Wnt (cWnt) pathway. How AV egg polarity regulates restricted activation of cWnt signaling at one pole of embryos is not well understood, but the PI's group has shown that in sea urchins and in the sea anemone Nematostella, this process occurs by the localized 'activation' of a key Wnt pathway protein called Disheveled (Dvl). Using biochemical techniques the PI's group has identified candidate proteins that are hypothesized to restrict Dvl activity to one end of the embryo. Hence, the goal of this research is to use molecular methods to functionally analyze how the identified candidate proteins regulate Dvl activity in sea urchins and Nematostella. This work will elucidate the molecular mechanisms that regulate the earliest separation of cell potential in animal embryos, and provide critical insight into the development and evolution of complex animals. The research involves graduate and undergraduate students, including students from groups under-represented in science. Public outreach includes an ongoing program with a local public high school teacher aimed at getting new immigrant students from Haiti and Central and South America interested in biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During embryonic development in most animals the establishment of the anterior-posterior (AP) and dorsal-ventral (DV) axes are two early events critical for normal embryonic development.  Over 95% of living animal species have distinct AP and DV axes and are referred to as "bilaterians" because of the bilateral symmetry imposed by the two primary axes.  The success of this clade of animals is most likely due to the trait of cephalization seen in bilaterians.  Thus, bilaterians have the central nervous system and associated sensory structures such as the visual and auditory systems and feeding structures such as the mouth localized to the organisms anterior end.  In contrast, none of the four early emerging non-bilaterian phyla — sponges, placozoans, ctenophores and cnidarians — have an AP axis indicating that this polarity evolved during bilaterian evolution.  Hence, the cnidarians, which are the closest outgroup to the bilaterians provide an important comparative system to reconstruct the evolution of the AP axis.  Cnidarians do not have an AP axis, but instead have an oral-aboral (OA) axis and the relationship of the bilaterian AP axis to the cnidarian OA axis is not well understood.  It is likely however, that understanding the molecular basis for the OA axis in cnidarians will provide key insight into AP axis evolution in bilaterians.

The AP axis is usually the first axis established during bilaterian embryogenesis and in many species its formation is strongly influenced by a polarity found in the unfertilized egg — the animal-vegetal (AV) axis.  During early embryogenesis in many bilaterian species key molecules that are asymmetrically localized at the egg's vegetal pole are mobilized to regulate the activation of an evolutionary conserved signaling pathway called the Wnt/b-catenin (cWnt) pathway in embryonic cells that will later contribute to the future posterior end of the embryo.  Signaling through this pathway establishes the endomesoderm germ layer that will later undergo the process of gastrulation to form the embryonic gut.  The cWnt pathway also regulates endomesoderm formation in cnidarians, but remarkably, this process takes place at the animal pole through the localized activation of cWnt at this pole.  The striking contrast in the sites of endomesoderm specification between invertebrate bilaterians and the Cnidaria led us to propose that endomesoderm evolved at the animal pole in the last common ancestor to the Bilateria and Cnidaria.  Additionally, we proposed that in the bilaterian lineage, endomesoderm specification was shifted to the vegetal pole, most likely by a change in the site of cWnt activation from the animal to the vegetal pole. 

The research proposed in the grant was aimed at gaining insight into this important evolutionary question based on several key observations made by the PI and colleagues.  We had shown that in sea urchins and in the cnidarian Nematostella, cWnt signaling is induced by localized activation of the Disheveled (Dvl) protein — a critical central regulatory protein in this pathway — at the vegetal pole in sea urchins and at the animal pole in Nematostella.  To identify the proteins that regulate Dvl function in sea urchins we exploited some advantageous features of the sea urchin egg and early embryo and used a method called co-immunoprecipitation using anti-Dvl antibodies to identify many Dvl-interacting proteins.  In the research proposed in the grant we performed functional studies on the role of several of these proteins in regulating the initial formation and the subsequent patterning of the AP axis during early development in sea urchins and in Nematostella.  We showed that one of these proteins in particular, Casein Kinase 1 delta, played a critical role in regulating the localized activation of the Dvl protein and the cWnt pathway in sea urchins.  However, the Nematostella homolog of this protein had no clear role in regulating endomesoderm formation.  Another Dvl interacting protein, Casein Kinase 2, was shown not to be required for regulating cWnt signaling in the early embryo.  Using RNA-seq we were able to identify several RNAs with predicted function in tethering Dvl to the vegetal cortex in the sea urchin, or in locally activating the protein during development.  We also demonstrated that the Axin protein, a critical negative component of the cWnt signaling pathway plays an early global role that is required for the normal formation of the AP axis in sea urchins and in Nematostella.  Additional functional analysis of Dvl-interacting proteins in sea urchins and Nematostella are ongoing.     

 During the granting period, our work involved graduate and undergraduate students, including students from groups under-represented in science.  We also trained biology faculty from the Miami-Dade Community College system in the use of sea urchins in hands on labs on their respective campuses.  We also participated in many outreach activities to local public schools to bring in middle and high school students to campus to participate in laboratory activities to inspire these students to become interested in biology.
